Epistemological issues in Euclid’s geometry || The question of diagrammatic constructions
1.1 The question of diagrammatic constructions

Euclid’s treatment of geometry has, through the ages, been
celebrated as a perfect deductive presentation of a science, and
certainly Euclid made great efforts to obtain a most careful logical
chain of truths. Book I in particular is impressive (see Lambert 1786,
Mueller 1981). Yet his proof-method gives a central role to diagrams,
for which reason Euclid’s work came under severe criticism in
the late nineteenth century. This is because, from the early
eighteenth century, there was a gradual dominance of algebraic methods
and a process of de-geometrization of mathematics, which evolved into
the so-called “arithmetization” of mathematics. Diagrams
were demoted to the role of mere auxiliaries in mathematical
reasoning, and a careful logical presentation of axioms and proofs was
implemented. One result of this movement would be Hilbert’s
work, examined below.

It seems nevertheless true that the origins of geometric thinking
have, in different cultures, always been associated with visuo-spatial
reasoning, and in particular with figures and diagrams. This is a key
reason for the celebrated beauty and appeal of geometry. Kant came
close to capturing the spirit of Euclid’s style of work when he
insisted that mathematical proof is based on the “construction
of concepts” in intuition. The geometer works with carefully
defined concepts, for which Euclid always shows how to construct
instances (thus, e.g., proposition 1 shows how to construct an
equilateral triangle given a line segment, and prop. 31 how to
construct a parallel to a given line). But, as Kant emphasized in a
famous passage of the Critique, logical analysis of the
concepts could never provide the means of proof – an appeal to
the construction (say, of a triangle) is required, offering a concrete
instance either in empirical intuition (an external representation) or
in pure intuition. Next, on the basis of the postulates, new elements
are incorporated into the construction, which make it possible to
interconnect concepts and obtain new results. So it is that one can
prove diagrammatically, e.g., that the angles of a triangle add up to
180º (which, by the way, requires an appeal to the parallel
postulate).

The proof of prop. 1 has famously been objected for having a
gap. Given a segment \(AB\), an equilateral triangle is constructed by
drawing two circles with \(AB\) as radius, one centered on \(A\) and
the other centered on \(B\). The objection is that Euclid has no
continuity principle, hence the existence of point \(C\) (the intersection
of both circles) is not warranted. But such an objection ignores the
proper role of diagrammatic reasoning in Euclid.  Manders (2008) has
provided an insightful analysis of how information is obtained from
text and diagram in the first books of the Elements, in careful
distribution of roles, which led him to distinguish between exact
information (from text only) and co-exact information (taken from the
diagram). Notice that a diagram is not just a figure, but a reasoning
tool, a semiotic element with rules of manipulation – and,
according to Manders, careful (implicit) rules for the extraction of
information. For further details on this topic, see the entry on
 diagrams, sections 4.2 and 4.3. 

In this connection it is worth mentioning a famous fallacious proof
that all triangles are isosceles, which Klein made well known. One can
show that this pseudo-proof violates the rules of the game of Euclid,
extracting exact information from the diagram, which is never allowed.
On the other hand, one should notice that Euclid’s postulates
are not so much axioms in the Hilbertian sense, as rules of
construction that are applied in the elaboration and handling of
diagrams. Most of Euclid's postulates establish that certain
constructions can be performed, the drawing of a line or a circle, the
meeting of two lines under certain conditions (this last is Euclid's
own formulation of postulate 5 “of the parallels”).  As
for the central role of such rules of construction in Ancient
geometry, it is interesting to remark that the Greeks said
‘diagramma’ to mean a mathematical proposition. 

But geometric knowledge, which began close to visual thinking
(Giaquinto 2007) and the practical manipulation of symbols, i.e.,
diagrams as concrete representations, gradually evolved to become a
more abstract edifice. Already with Euclid, Archimedes and Apollonius
there is an effort to give form to well-crafted concepts, which make
precise, ideal, and general what was suggested by intuition; likewise,
the way of handling diagrams is anything but naive (see e.g. prop. 10
in Book III, but also props. 7, 14 or 27 in Book I). And in due
course, a critical stage was attained, when the assumptions of
geometric knowledge were made explicit and subjected to scrutiny,
looking for deeper foundations and for alternatives. At this stage,
represented above all by the nineteenth century, the diagram had to be
relegated in favor of more explicit, abstract, relational methods for
the analysis of theoretical assumptions and developments.
